qas.question: What's the name of the vehicle where the musicians play?
What do devotees follow during a particular religious celebration?
Who are usually included the group comparsa?
What is used in some of the festive fights?
What is the goal of the Carnival painters?

answers.text: to paint as many people as you can

context: Comparsas are held throughout the week, consisting of large groups "of dancers dancing and traveling on the streets, followed by <a0_0>a Carrosa<a0_0/> (carriage) where the musicians play. The Comparsa is a development of African processions where groups of devotees follow <a1_0>a given saint or deity<a1_0/> during a particular religious celebration". One of the most popular comparsas of Fiesta de Carnaval is the male group comparsa, usually composed of <a2_0>notable men from the community<a2_0/> who dress up in outlandish costumes or cross-dress and dance to compete for money and prizes. Other popular activities include body painting and <a3_0>flour<a3_0/> fighting. "On the last day of Carnival painters flood the street to paint each other. This simply means that a mixture of water paint and water or raw eggs is used to paint people on the streets, the goal being <a4_0>to paint as many people as you can<a4_0/>".
